Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Archaeological investigation of foodways and social organization in the Americas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation project will use archaeological plant and animal evidence to advance knowledge about how food was utilized, how food related to social organization, and more broadly, how sociopolitical complexity developed in the human past. The project will not only generate detailed data on faunal and botanical remains to advance archaeological theory, but will also provide time depth and comparative data for understanding modern societal challenges related to food and inequality. The project will support and strengthen international scientific collaborations and student training in STEM research. Public and community science outreach and conservation of local historical heritage will also be fostered through community and researcher collaborations.

This project builds upon recent calls by scholars to develop a more social approach to the archaeological study of food practices, including consideration of the relationship between people and food in everyday and ritual settings within a social and cultural system. The investigators will address the relationship between food and social organization through a thorough analysis of exceptionally well-preserved faunal and botanical remains of an early village in the Mixteca Alta of Oaxaca, Mexico. The archaeological site of Etlatongois is temporally situated at the dawn of social complexity in the Oaxacan region of Mesoamerica, ca. 1000 BC. Zooarchaeological and paleoethnobotanical analyses will be carried out in one of the largest faunal and floral samples ever excavated for the region, in terms of volume of material pertaining to a single time period. The excellent preservation of the sample will also allow for the study of the comparative morphology of maize to better understand the development of this domesticate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Victor Emmanuel Salazar Chavez completed research for his dissertation Archaeological Investigation of Foodways and Social Organization in the Americas, supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. The project studied, through the perspective of the archaeological site of Etlatongo, the interdependent relationship between people and food, at a time when Mesoamerica reached a series of critical thresholds in social relationships and foodways circa 1000 BC. Engaging in questions concerning the constitution of status differences and political authority, the project contributes to more nuanced understandings of how social relationships and sociopolitical complexity can be shaped through food-related practices.

During his funding period, Salazar Chavez spent one year working with one of the largest faunal and botanical assemblages ever excavated in the Mixteca Alta in terms of volume of material pertaining to the Early Formative period, making a significant contribution to the limited but notable research made to date in the region. The research took place in multiple locations due to use and analysis of distinct archaeological materials. Salazar Chavez was able to analyze a faunal collection at an archaeological laboratory at the Universidad Autonoma de San Luis Potosi (UASLP/ Autonomous University of San Luis Potosi), where a large zooarchaeological reference collection and reference manuals are housed. The botanical collection, on the other hand, was analyzed at the archaeological laboratories in the ex-Convent of Cuilapan of the Instituto Nacional de Antropologia e Historia (INAH/ National Institute of Anthropology and History) in Oaxaca, where equipment and materials necessary for a correct botanical analysis are held. Finally, a smaller but substantial shell sample was taken to the Museum of Templo Mayor in Mexico City for its analysis. The multi-site nature of the project allowed for the successful and timely completion of the research.

These various analyses yielded over 20,000 studied materials. One of the most significant results was the findings on early maize consumption. Recent research in Early Formative Mesoamerica has proposed that maize only became more prevalent in the diet during later periods. Our study shows, however, that the history and adoption of maize as a staple is not so straightforward. Levels of maize production and consumption at the site of Etlatongo show a heavy reliance on this grain, contrary to previous assumptions. Moreover, differential use of maize varieties within different areas at the site suggests that some species were valued differently, possibly imbued with symbolic meaning.

The project also examined various other social and political expressions at Etlatongo through the contrasting role of animals and plants in the context of both everyday household activities and public ceremonial events. Among these are the study of social inequalities expressed through diet, sources of wealth through animal production, redistribution of foods, trade and regulation of resources, and the manipulation of the symbolic meaning of special foodstuffs. The project was able to successfully address these issues, which sheds significant light on the formation of social and political relationships in early agricultural communities in Mesoamerica.

Furthermore, the project aimed to strengthen academic relationships between the United States and Mexico, as well as the diffusion of research based on an underrepresented specialization in archaeology. Academic collaborations between George Washington University (GWU) and the Mexican institutions of UASLP, INAH-Oaxaca, and Templo Mayor Museum were achieved through scientific and practical exchanges. These institutions provided important accommodations and scientific equipment, without which this project would have not been successfully completed. Furthermore, we collaborated with various Mexican archaeology and graduate students, who were involved in different stages of the project, gaining experience in zooarchaeology, paleoethnobotany and malacological analysis. This experience allowed the students to network with other researchers and will significantly strengthen their academic and professional development.
